The search for simple and cost-effective catalysts incorporating earth abundant and environmentally friendly metals for the depolymerization of plastic waste is a crucial area of research. In this work, we report the reductive depolymerization of various polyesters and the polycarbonate PC.BPA catalyzed by the commercially available iron-based catalysts Fe(OTf)2 and Fe(CO)5, using pinacolborane as a mild reducing agent. These catalytic systems produced the corresponding diols with good to excellent yields under mild reaction conditions. This methodology not only facilitates the depolymerization of plastics but also contributes to the sustainable synthesis of valuable diols, offering a promising pathway for both waste valorization and the production of high-demand chemical intermediates. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Waste valorization Reductive depolymerization Polyesters Polycarbonates Iron catalysts Diols Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Plastic and biomass waste can pollute the environment if not properly managed. Converting these wastes into value-added compounds helps mitigate pollution, reduce landfill use, and promote a circular economy where waste is transformed into valuable resources. Numerous methodologies have been explored to convert biomass resources into high-value compounds, including diols, furan derivatives, biofuels, polymers, and a broad range of industrial raw materials [1–24]. These compounds can replace conventional petrochemical-derived products, providing more sustainable alternatives with potentially lower environmental impacts. In recent years, significant advances have also been made by the scientific community towards the valorization of plastic waste into value-added compounds through the development of innovative methodologies [25–44]. One of these promising approaches is the reductive depolymerization, which has demonstrated good efficiency in transforming polyesters, polycarbonates and polyamides into a wide range of compounds with considerable industrial relevance [45]. However, some of these methods use expensive catalysts that contain toxic metals such as ruthenium, iridium, lanthanide and zirconium [46–51]. The use of these metals not only increases the cost of the process, but also raises environmental and safety concerns due to the potential toxicity and difficulty in recycling these materials. As a result, there is growing interest in developing alternative, more sustainable catalytic systems that are both cost-effective and less harmful to the environment. In recent years, our group has demonstrated that the reductive depolymerization of a variety of polyesters and polycarbonates can be achieved using inexpensive catalysts based on earth-abundant and environmentally friendly metals, such as molybdenum, zinc, manganese, magnesium, barium, and calcium [52–60]. Iron is the most abundant transition metal and the fourth most abundant element in the Earth’s crust, the features such as environmentally benign, low cost and relatively scarce toxicity make iron-based catalysts particularly attractive. To date, only two examples involving iron pincer complexes have been reported for the depolymerization of synthetic polymers: one targeting the polyester Dynacol 7360 [61], and the other the polycarbonate PPC [62], both via transfer hydrogenation. These studies highlight the potential of iron-based systems in polymer breakdown, yet the scope remains extremely limited. In light of the increasing demand for sustainable and efficient methods for plastic recycling, and driven by the need for catalysts based on low-toxicity, cost-effective, and readily available metals, we aim to expand the use of iron catalysts in this field. Specifically, we investigated the application of Fe(OTf)2 and Fe(CO)5, both inexpensive and commercially accessible iron complexes, as catalysts for the reductive depolymerization of plastic waste. In this context, we employed pinacolborane (HBpin) as a mild and selective reducing agent, aiming to develop a practical and efficient system for the chemical recycling of plastics. 2 Results and discussion An investigation was conducted into the reductive depolymerization of various polyester plastic waste, including PCL, P4HB, PBS, PBA, and PES, using Fe(OTf)2 as a catalyst and boranes as reducing agents under atmospheric conditions. Initially, we focused on optimizing reaction parameters for PCL depolymerization (Table 1 ). The reaction with 5 mol % Fe(OTf)2, 3 mol % KO t Bu, and 3 equivalents of HBpin in toluene at 80 °C for 16 h resulted in a 89 % yield of pinBO(CH2)6OBpin (Table 1, entry 1). By reducing the catalyst amount to 2 mol % and extending the reaction time to 44 h at 110 ºC, the yield decreased to 71 % (Table 1, entry 2). Similarly, reducing the amount of HBpin to 2.2 equivalents led to a decrease in the yield of pinBO(CH₂)₆OBpin to 73 % (Table 1, entry 3). We also investigated the effect of temperature on PCL depolymerization. At 60 °C, the reaction gave pinBO(CH2)6OBpin with 87 % yield, and 9 % of unreacted PCL (Table 1, entry 4) and at room temperature, pinBO(CH2)6OBpin was obtained in 51 % along with 46 % of unreacted PCL, after 92 h (Table 1, entry 5). The depolymerization of PCL was also explored using HBcat as the reducing agent. However, the reaction did not take place (Table 1, entry 6). Similar results were also obtained when this reaction was carried out using the silanes PhSiH3 or 1,1,3,3-tetramethyldisiloxane (TMDS) as the reducing agents (Table 1, entries 7 and 8). An investigation using HBpin as the reducing agent into the absence of the base KO t Bu was also conducted. It was observed that after 44 h at 110 °C, the reaction did not proceed (Table 1, entry 9). Similarly, when both the reducing agent and base were absent, there was no reaction observed (Table 1, entry 10). Finally, the reaction carried out in the absence of a catalyst, using HBpin and KO t Bu at 110 °C, did not proceed even after 44 h (Table 1, entry 11). The depolymerization of PCL was also performed using the Fe(OTf)₂/HBpin/KO t Bu system, followed by hydrolysis in a methanol/NaOH solution, yielding 1,6-hexanediol with 85 % yield after 16 h (Fig. 1 ). These results highlight the effectiveness of Fe(OTf)₂ as a catalyst in the transformation of PCL, providing significant conversion and high selectivity toward the desired diol. We also tested the use of FeCl2 (5 mol %) as the catalyst for the reductive depolymerization of PCL in the presence of 3 mol % KO t Bu and 3 equivalents of HBpin in toluene at reflux temperature. However, even after 48 h, the reaction did not proceed. The depolymerization of a poly(4-hydroxybutyrate) (P4HB) sample, obtained from a non-infected commercial surgical suture, was also investigated. The reaction was carried out with 5 mol % Fe(OTf)2, 3 equivalents of HBpin, and 3 mol % KO t Bu in toluene under reflux conditions, resulting in an 85 % yield of pinBO(CH2)4OBpin after 20 h (Fig. 2 ). After hydrolysis of the reaction mixture, 1,4-butanediol was obtained in a 79 % yield. A sample of polybutylene succinate (PBS), derived from a Delta Q eQo coffee capsule, a Portuguese coffee brand, was also subjected to depolymerization. This reaction was catalyzed by 5 mol % Fe(OTf)2, producing pinBO(CH2)4OBpin with 73 % yield and 20 % yield of 1,4-butanediol after 20 h (Fig. 3 ). When the reductive depolymerization of PBS was followed by hydrolysis, 1,4-butanediol was selectively obtained with an 87 % yield. The efficiency of the Fe(OTf)₂ catalyst was also evaluated in the valorization of a granulated sample of poly(1,4-butylene adipate) (PBA), leading to the production of pinBO(CH₂)₆OBpin and pinBO(CH₂)₄OBpin with 88 % yields after 16 h (Fig. 4 ). The corresponding diols, 1,6-hexanediol and 1,4-butanediol, were obtained with 84 % yield after hydrolysis. The reductive depolymerization of a commercially available granulated sample of poly(ethylene succinate) (PES) was also successfully carried out in the presence of 5 mol % Fe(OTf)2 at a relatively low temperature of 60 °C. This process led to the formation of pinBO(CH2)4OBpin and pinBO(CH2)2OBpin with excellent yields of 95 %. Subsequent hydrolysis of the borylated diols resulted in the production of 1,4-butanediol and ethylene glycol, with 90 % yield (Fig. 5 ). The iron catalyst Fe(OTf)₂ was also evaluated for the reductive depolymerization of polycarbonate PC.BPA, using a sample obtained from a CD disc. After optimizing the reaction conditions, we found that the depolymerization required a higher catalyst loading of Fe(OTf)2 (10 mol %) and an elevated temperature of 140 °C. Under these conditions, the reaction produced borylated bisphenol A and MeOBpin in moderate yields after 44 h (Fig. 6 ). Subsequent hydrolysis of the products led to the formation of bisphenol A and methanol. These results highlight the potential of Fe(OTf)₂ for the reductive depolymerization of polycarbonates. However, its efficiency in polycarbonate depolymerization was lower than in polyester depolymerization, probably due to the increased difficulty in reducing carbonate groups, which are more electronically stable and less reactive than ester groups. The diols 1,4-butanediol, 1,6-hexanediol, bisphenol A, ethylene glycol, and methanol, obtained in moderate to excellent yields from the coversion of plastic waste, are crucial intermediates in a wide range of industries, including chemical, pharmaceutical, agriculture, cosmetics, and automotive, etc. These compounds play essential roles in the production of various products, such as plastics, solvents, pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and automotive components. The ability to generate these intermediates from plastic waste not only offers an effective solution for plastic recycling and valorization but also contributes significantly to sustainability and reducing the dependence on fossil-based raw materials. To evaluate the potential of Fe(OTf)2 for use in multiple consecutive depolymerization reactions, we investigated its catalytic efficiency in the reductive depolymerization of PCL. The initial reaction was performed using 0.5 mmol of PCL, 5 mol % Fe(OTf)₂, 3 equivalents of HBpin, and 3 mol % KO t Bu in toluene at 110 °C for 16 h. The yield of pinBO(CH2)6OBpin was determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy using mesitylene as an internal standard. For subsequent reactions, without isolating or purifying the catalyst, additional portions of PCL, HBpin, and KO t Bu were added directly to the reaction mixture, which was then heated again under the same conditions for 16 h. The first reaction afforded pinBO(CH2)6OBpin in 90 % yield. In contrast, successive reactions showed a marked decline in efficiency, with yields dropping to 43 % in the second reaction, 15 % in the third, and complete suppression of product formation in the fourth reaction. The promising outcomes achieved in the reductive depolymerization of plastic waste catalyzed by Fe(OTf)2 led us to investigate this reaction using Fe(CO)5 as the catalyst. For instance, the depolymerization of PCL was conducted with 5 mol % of Fe(CO)5, 3 equivalents of HBpin, and 3 mol % of KO t Bu, in refluxing toluene, with production of pinBO(CH2)6OBpin with 92 % yield, after 44 h (Fig. 7 ). The diol 1,6-hexanediol was also obtained in excellent yield (87 %), when the reductive depolymerization was followed by hydrolysis. The reductive depolymerization of the polyester P4HB was explored using 5 mol % of Fe(CO)5, 3 equivalents of HBpin, and 10 mol % of KO t Bu in toluene at 110 °C for 44 h, resulting in an 72 % yield of pinBO(CH2)6OBpin and 18 % yield of 1,4-butanediol. After hydrolysis of the reaction mixture, 1,4-butanediol was obtained with 83 % yield (Fig. 8 ). Good yields were also obtained in the reductive depolymerization of PBS catalyzed by Fe(CO)5 (5 mol %) with the formation of pinBO(CH2)4OBpin in 75 % yield, along with 18 % of unreated PBS after 44 h. The hydrolysis of the reaction mixture produced 1,4-butanediol in 70 % yield (Fig. 9 ). The hydroborylation of PBA and PES polyesters were further examined using Fe(CO)5 as the catalyst in toluene at 110 °C. From the reaction of PBA were obtained the corresponding borylated diols with 88 % yields after 44 h (Fig. 10 ). Hydrolysis of the reaction mixture produced 1,6-hexanediol and 1,4-butanediol in 84 % yield. However, the depolymerization of this polyester required a higher catalyst amount (10 mol %). This catalyst also demonstrated excellent performance in the reductive depolymerization of the polyester PES, leading to the formation of borylated diols with 94 % yield in refluxing toluene after 44 h (Fig. 11 ). The corresponding diols were then obtained with 91 % yield by hydrolyzing the reaction mixture. Finally, we investigated the reductive depolymerization of the polycarbonate PC.BPA catalyzed by Fe(CO)5. This reaction was carried out with 5 mol % Fe(CO)5, 3 equivalents of HBpin and 10 mol % KO t Bu at high temperature (140 °C) for 44 h, producing borylated bisphenol A and MeOBpin with good yields (Fig. 12 ). After hydrolysis, bisphenol A and methanol were obtained with 75 and 67 % yields, respectively. Based on the results reported in the literature using iron pincer catalysts for depolymerization via transfer hydrogenation [57,58], we decided to investigate the reaction of the polyester PCL with methanol and ethanol, catalyzed by Fe(OTf)2 and Fe(CO)5 at 110 °C. However, we did not observe the reductive depolymerization of these polymers. When the reactions of PCL were carried out with methanol and ethanol in the presence of KO t Bu, the depolymerization occurred through alcoholysis rather than reduction resulting in the formation of methyl 6-hydroxyhexanoate and ethyl 6-hydroxyhexanoate with excellent yields (Fig. 13 ). We also performed 11B NMR spectra of the reaction between HBpin and KO t Bu, HBpin and Fe(OTf)2, and also HBpin, KO t Bu and Fe(OTf)2 (Figure S24). From the reaction between HBpin and KO t Bu in toluene-d8 at 110 °C, we observed the release of a gas, probably H2, and a small signal at 21.71 ppm in the 11B NMR spectrum. This signal can be assigned to the species t BuO-Bpin, as reported by other authors [63]. A signal at 22.65 ppm was observed in the 11B NMR spectrum following the reaction between HBpin and Fe(OTf)₂ after 30 min at 110 °C, suggesting activation of HBpin by the catalyst. This newly formed species, most likely a Fe–H complex resulting from B–H bond activation in the borane, does not effectively reduce PCL, as no reaction was observed in the absence of KO t Bu (Table 1, entry 9). Two signals were observed at 21.6 and 22.6 ppm in the 11B NMR spectrum in the reaction between HBpin, KO t Bu, and Fe(OTf)₂, which may corresponding to the aforementioned species. As previously mentioned, we found that the reductive depolymerization of PCL proceeds efficiently only in the presence of both the catalyst and the base. This suggests that the reaction mechanism likely involves the formation of additional hydride species with enhanced catalytic activity, which may participate in the reduction of ester or carbonate groups following coordination with the polymer. Additionally, Lewis acid activation of the ester or carbonate groups may further promote the reduction. The triflate anion is recognized for its exceptional stability and electron-withdrawing properties, which enhance the Lewis acidity of the catalysts. Other mechanisms based on metal hydrides cannot be excluded. Table 2 presents a comparison of the yields obtained in the reductive depolymerization of the polyester PCL and the polycarbonate PC.BPA, using iron catalysts Fe(OTf)₂ and Fe(CO)₅, as well as various Mo, Zn, Mn, Mg, Ba, and Ca-based catalysts, with HBpin as the reducing agent. The results obtained from the reduction of PCL led to excellent yields of both pinBO(CH₂)₆OBpin and 1,6-hexanediol after hydrolysis. The reaction required the presence of 5 mol % of iron catalyst, a loading similar to that used in depolymerizations catalyzed by Mg(OTf)2 or Zn(OAc)2·2H2O. However, the reaction using the catalysts Zn(OTf)2 and Mn2(CO)10, also proceeded successfully with very low catalyst loadings. Regarding the reductive depolymerization of the polycarbonate PC.BPA using Fe(OTf)2 and Fe(CO)5 as the catalysts, the reaction catalyzed by Fe(CO)5 led to good yields (∼70–80 %) of both the borylated diols and the corresponding diols after hydrolysis. In contrast, the Fe(OTf)2-catalyzed depolymerization of PC.BPA provided only moderate yields (∼60 %) of the desired products, even under higher catalyst loading conditions. These yields were also lower than those obtained with other catalytic systems. 3 Conclusions In this work, we demonstrate that the commercially available iron compounds Fe(OTf)2 and Fe(CO)5 are cost-effective catalysts for the reductive depolymerization of various polyester and polycarbonate plastics using HBpin as the reducing agent. This methodology successfully depolymerizes a range of plastics into their corresponding diols with good to excellent yields, under mild reaction conditions. When comparing the reactivity of the two iron catalysts, we found that reactions with Fe(OTf)₂ typically required lower catalyst amounts (∼5 mol %) and shorter reaction times (∼20 h) compared to Fe(CO)₅, which needed 44 h and, in some cases, 10 mol % of catalyst. This methodology offers the advantage of using simple catalysts made from an earth-abundant metal. Additionally, the absence of complex ligands in these systems, unlike the iron pincer complexes reported in the literature [61,62], makes the process more economical and scalable. The excellent results obtained with Fe(OTf)2 and Fe(CO)5 also highlight that iron-based catalysts offer an environmentally friendly and efficient alternative for the depolymerization of plastic waste. These catalysts not only facilitate the depolymerization of plastics but also contribute to the sustainable synthesis of valuable diols, offering a promising pathway for both waste valorization and the production of high-demand chemical intermediates. The use of iron-based catalysts aligns with the growing demand for green chemistry solutions, reducing reliance on more hazardous or expensive catalytic systems while supporting circular economy principles. 4 Materials and methods All the reactions were carried out under atmospheric conditions and without using any dry solvent. Iron catalysts, boranes, silanes and solvents were obtained from commercial suppliers and were used without further purification. Polymers employed in the study included polycaprolactone (PCL) (average Mw ∼10,000), poly(1,4-butylene adipate) (PBA) (average Mw ∼12,000) and poly(ethylene succinate) (PES) (average Mw ∼10,000) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich, polybutylene succinate (PBS) from a Delta Q eQo coffee capsule, poly(4-hydroxybutyrate) (P4HB) from a non-infected commercial surgical suture, from B. Braun Medical Portugal and bisphenol A polycarbonate (PC.BPA) from a CD Disc. 1H, 13C and 11B NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance II+ 400 MHz spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in parts per million (ppm) downfield from an internal standard. 4.1 General procedure for the reductive depolymerization of plastic waste catalyzed by Fe(OTf)2 followed by hydrolysis To a solution of PCL, P4HB, PBS, PBA, PES or PC.BPA (0.5 mmol) in toluene (3 mL) was added the Fe(OTf)2 (5–10 mol %), HBpin (3–6 equiv.) and KO t Bu (3–10 mol %). The reaction mixture was stirred at 80–140 °C, under air atmosphere, in a closed vessel, for 16–44 h. After evaporation of the reaction mixture, the hydrolysis was carried out with a 1 M NaOH aqueous solution (2.5 mL) and MeOH (2.5 mL) at 60 °C for 16 h. The alcohol was extracted with dichloromethane (3 × 20 mL) and the organic phases were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered and concentrated in vacuo. The products were purified by silica gel column chromatography using the appropriate mixtures of hexane/ethyl acetate, affording the corresponding pure diols, which are all known products. 4.2 General procedure for the reductive depolymerization of plastic waste catalyzed by Fe(CO)5 followed by hydrolysis To a solution of PCL, P4HB, PBS, PBA, PES or PC.BPA (0.5 mmol) in toluene (3 mL) was added the Fe(CO)5 (5–10 mol %), HBpin (3–6 equiv.) and KO t Bu (5–10 mol %). The reaction mixture was stirred at 110–140 °C, under air atmosphere, in a closed vessel, for 44 h. After evaporation of the reaction mixture, the hydrolysis was carried out with a 1 M NaOH aqueous solution (2.5 mL) and MeOH (2.5 mL) at 60 °C for 16 h. The alcohol was extracted with dichloromethane (3 × 20 mL) and the organic phases were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered and concentrated in vacuo. The products were purified by silica gel column chromatography using the appropriate mixtures of hexane/ethyl acetate, affording the corresponding pure diols, which are all known products. 4.3 General procedure for the alcoholysis of PCL catalyzed by iron catalysts To a solution of PCL (0.5 mmol) in methanol or ethanol (3 mL) was added Fe(OTf)2 or Fe(CO)5 catalysts (1 mol %) and KO t Bu (5 mol %) and the reaction mixture was stirred at 110 °C, under air atmosphere, in a closed vessel for 6 h. After evaporation, the products were purified by silica gel column chromatography using the appropriate mixtures of hexane/ethyl acetate, affording the corresponding pure diols, which are all known products. 4.4 Use of catalyst Fe(OTf)2 in several consecutive reactions To a solution of PCL (57 mg, 0.5 mmol) in toluene (3 mL) was added Fe(OTf)2 (5 mol %, 8.8 mg), KO t Bu (3 mol %, 1.7 mg) and HBpin (0.22 mL, 3 equiv.). After stirring the reaction mixture at 110 °C during 16 h, under air atmosphere, in a closed vessel, the yield of pinBO(CH2)6OBpin was determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy using mesitylene (0.07 mL, 0.5 mmol) as the internal standard. Without separating the catalyst, subsequent catalytic cycles were performed by adding PCL (57 mg, 0.5 mmol), HBpin (0.22 mL, 3 equiv.), KO t Bu (3 mol %, 1.7 mg) and mesytilene (0.07 mL, 0.5 mmol) directly to the reaction mixture. The mixture was then stirred at 110 °C for 16 h. The yields of each catalytic cycle were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy using mesitylene as the internal standard. coredata.dc:description: The search for simple and cost-effective catalysts incorporating earth abundant and environmentally friendly metals for the depolymerization of plastic waste is a crucial area of research. In this work, we report the reductive depolymerization of various polyesters and the polycarbonate PC.BPA catalyzed by the commercially available iron-based catalysts Fe(OTf)2 and Fe(CO)5, using pinacolborane as a mild reducing agent. These catalytic systems produced the corresponding diols with good to excellent yields under mild reaction conditions. This methodology not only facilitates the depolymerization of plastics but also contributes to the sustainable synthesis of valuable diols, offering a promising pathway for both waste valorization and the production of high-demand chemical intermediates.
